4  4 
5    *Readable*: 5    *Readable*:
6    Understanding Guideline 3.1 6    Understanding Guideline 3.1
7  7 
8    *Guideline 3.1: * Make text content readable and understandable. 8    *Guideline 3.1: * Make text content readable and understandable.
9  9 
10  10 
11      Intent of Guideline 3.1 11      Intent of Guideline 3.1
12  12 
13The intent of this guideline is to allow text content to be read by 13The intent of this guideline is to allow text content to be read by
14users and by assistive technology, and to ensure that information 14users and by assistive technology, and to ensure that information
15necessary for understanding it is available. 15necessary for understanding it is available.
16  16 
17People with disabilities experience text in many different ways. For 17People with disabilities experience text in many different ways. For
18some the experience is visual; for some it is auditory; for some it is 18some the experience is visual; for some it is auditory; for some it is
19tactile; for still others it is both visual and auditory. Some users 19tactile; for still others it is both visual and auditory. Some users
20experience great difficulty in recognizing written words yet understand 20experience great difficulty in recognizing written words yet understand
21extremely complex and sophisticated documents when the text is read 21extremely complex and sophisticated documents when the text is read
22aloud, or when key processes and ideas are illustrated visually or 22aloud, or when key processes and ideas are illustrated visually or
23interpreted as sign language. For some users, it is difficult to infer 23interpreted as sign language. For some users, it is difficult to infer
24the meaning of a word or phrase from context, especially when the word 24the meaning of a word or phrase from context, especially when the word
25or phrase is used in an unusual way or has been given a specialized 25or phrase is used in an unusual way or has been given a specialized
26meaning; for these users the ability to read and understand may depend 26meaning; for these users the ability to read and understand may depend
27on the availability of specific definitions or the expanded forms of 27on the availability of specific definitions or the expanded forms of
28acronyms or abbreviations. User agents, including speech-enabled as well 28acronyms or abbreviations. User agents, including speech-enabled as well
29as graphical applications, may be unable to present text correctly 29as graphical applications, may be unable to present text correctly
30unless the language and direction of the text are identified; while 30unless the language and direction of the text are identified; while
31these may be minor problems for most users, they can be enormous 31these may be minor problems for most users, they can be enormous
32barriers for users with disabilities. In cases where meaning cannot be 32barriers for users with disabilities. In cases where meaning cannot be
33determined without pronunciation information (for example, certain 33determined without pronunciation information (for example, certain
34Japanese Kanji characters), pronunciation information must be available 34Japanese Kanji characters), pronunciation information must be available
35as well 35as well
36  36 
37  37 
38      Advisory Techniques for Guideline 3.1 (not success criteria specific) 38      Advisory Techniques for Guideline 3.1 (not success criteria specific)
39  39 
40Specific techniques for meeting each Success Criterion for this 40Specific techniques for meeting each Success Criterion for this
41guideline are listed in the understanding sections for each Success 41guideline are listed in the understanding sections for each Success
42Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for 42Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for
43addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success 43addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success
44criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or 44criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or
45sufficient for meeting any success criteria, but can make certain types 45sufficient for meeting any success criteria, but can make certain types
46of Web content more accessible to more people. 46of Web content more accessible to more people.

152    *Language of Page*: 152    *Language of Page*:
153    Understanding SC 3.1.1 153    Understanding SC 3.1.1
154  154 
155    *3.1.1 155    *3.1.1
156    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#meaning-doc-lang-id> 156    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#meaning-doc-lang-id>
157    Language of Page:* The default human language 157    Language of Page:* The default human language
158    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#human-langdef> of 158    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#human-langdef> of
159    each Web page 159    each Web page
160    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#webpagedef> can be 160    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#webpagedef> can be
161    programmatically determined 161    programmatically determined
162    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#programmaticallydetermineddef>. 162    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#programmaticallydetermineddef>.
163    (Level A) 163    (Level A)
164  164 
165  165 
166      Intent of this Success Criterion 166      Intent of this Success Criterion
167  167 
168The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that content 168The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that content
169developers provide information in the Web page that user agents need to 169developers provide information in the Web page that user agents need to
170present text and other linguistic content correctly. Both assistive 170present text and other linguistic content correctly. Both assistive
171technologies and conventional user agents can render text more 171technologies and conventional user agents can render text more
172accurately when the language of the Web page is identified. Screen 172accurately when the language of the Web page is identified. Screen
173readers can load the correct pronunciation rules. Visual browsers can 173readers can load the correct pronunciation rules. Visual browsers can
174display characters and scripts correctly. Media players can show 174display characters and scripts correctly. Media players can show
175captions correctly. As a result, users with disabilities will be better 175captions correctly. As a result, users with disabilities will be better
176able to understand the content. 176able to understand the content.
177  177 
178The default human language of the Web page is the default 178The default human language of the Web page is the default
179text-processing language as discussed in Internationalization Best 179text-processing language as discussed in Internationalization Best
180Practices: Specifying Language in XHTML & HTML Content 180Practices: Specifying Language in XHTML & HTML Content
181<http://www.w3.org/TR/i18n-html-tech-lang/>. When a Web page uses 181<http://www.w3.org/TR/i18n-html-tech-lang/>. When a Web page uses
182several languages, the default text-processing language is the language 182several languages, the default text-processing language is the language
183which is used most. (If several languages are used equally, the first 183which is used most. (If several languages are used equally, the first
184language used should be chosen as the default human language.) 184language used should be chosen as the default human language.)
185  185 
186/Note: / For multilingual sites targeting Conformance Level A, the 186/Note: / For multilingual sites targeting Conformance Level A, the
187Working Group strongly encourages developers to follow Success Criterion 187Working Group strongly encourages developers to follow Success Criterion
1883.1.2 as well even though that is a Level AA Success Criterion. 1883.1.2 as well even though that is a Level AA Success Criterion.

192  192 
193This Success Criterion helps: 193This Success Criterion helps:
194  194 
195  * 195  *
196  196 
197    people who use screen readers or other technologies that convert 197    people who use screen readers or other technologies that convert
198    text into synthetic speech; 198    text into synthetic speech;
199  199 
200  * 200  *
201  201 
202    people who find it difficult to read written material with fluency 202    people who find it difficult to read written material with fluency
203    and accuracy, such as recognizing characters and alphabets or 203    and accuracy, such as recognizing characters and alphabets or
204    decoding words; 204    decoding words;
205  205 
206  * 206  *
207  207 
208    people with certain cognitive, language and learning disabilities 208    people with certain cognitive, language and learning disabilities
209    who use text-to-speech software 209    who use text-to-speech software
210  210 
211  * 211  *
212  212 
213    people who rely on captions for synchronized media. 213    people who rely on captions for synchronized media.

220    *Example 1. A Web page with content in two languages* 220    *Example 1. A Web page with content in two languages*
221  221 
222    A Web page produced in Germany and written in HTML includes content 222    A Web page produced in Germany and written in HTML includes content
223    in both German and English, but most of the content is in German. 223    in both German and English, but most of the content is in German.
224    The default human language is identified as German (de) by the lang 224    The default human language is identified as German (de) by the lang
225    attribute on the html element. 225    attribute on the html element.

243Criterion if all of the WCAG 2.0 conformance requirements 243Criterion if all of the WCAG 2.0 conformance requirements
244<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#conformance-reqs> have 244<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#conformance-reqs> have
245been met. 245been met.

300  300 
301Web page 301Web page
302  302 
303    a non-embedded resource obtained from a single URI using HTTP plus 303    a non-embedded resource obtained from a single URI using HTTP plus
304    any other resources that are used in the rendering or intended to be 304    any other resources that are used in the rendering or intended to be
305    rendered together with it by a user agent 305    rendered together with it by a user agent
306    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#useragentdef> 306    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#useragentdef>
307  307 
308    /Note 1: /Although any "other resources" would be rendered together 308    /Note 1: /Although any "other resources" would be rendered together
309    with the primary resource, they would not necessarily be rendered 309    with the primary resource, they would not necessarily be rendered
310    simultaneously with each other. 310    simultaneously with each other.
311  311 
312    /Note 2: /For the purposes of conformance with these guidelines, a 312    /Note 2: /For the purposes of conformance with these guidelines, a
313    resource must be "non-embedded" within the scope of conformance to 313    resource must be "non-embedded" within the scope of conformance to
314    be considered a Web page. 314    be considered a Web page.
315  315

319    and XML (AJAX). The program lives entirely at 319    and XML (AJAX). The program lives entirely at
320    http://example.com/mail, but includes an inbox, a contacts area and 320    http://example.com/mail, but includes an inbox, a contacts area and
321    a calendar. Links or buttons are provided that cause the inbox, 321    a calendar. Links or buttons are provided that cause the inbox,
322    contacts, or calendar to display, but do not change the URI of the 322    contacts, or calendar to display, but do not change the URI of the
323    page as a whole. 323    page as a whole.

327  327 
328    /Example 4: /When you enter "http://shopping.example.com/" in your 328    /Example 4: /When you enter "http://shopping.example.com/" in your
329    browser, you enter a movie-like interactive shopping environment 329    browser, you enter a movie-like interactive shopping environment
330    where you visually move around in a store dragging products off of 330    where you visually move around in a store dragging products off of
331    the shelves around you and into a visual shopping cart in front of 331    the shelves around you and into a visual shopping cart in front of
332    you. Clicking on a product causes it to be demonstrated with a 332    you. Clicking on a product causes it to be demonstrated with a
333    specification sheet floating alongside. This might be a single-page 333    specification sheet floating alongside. This might be a single-page
334    Web site or just one page within a Web site. 334    Web site or just one page within a Web site.

365    *Language of Parts*: 365    *Language of Parts*:
366    Understanding SC 3.1.2 366    Understanding SC 3.1.2
367  367 
368    *3.1.2 368    *3.1.2
369    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#meaning-other-lang-id> 369    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#meaning-other-lang-id>
370    Language of Parts:* The human language 370    Language of Parts:* The human language
371    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#human-langdef> of 371    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#human-langdef> of
372    each passage or phrase in the content can be programmatically 372    each passage or phrase in the content can be programmatically
373    determined 373    determined
374    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#programmaticallydetermineddef> 374    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#programmaticallydetermineddef>
375    except for proper names, technical terms, words of indeterminate 375    except for proper names, technical terms, words of indeterminate
376    language, and words or phrases that have become part of the 376    language, and words or phrases that have become part of the
377    vernacular of the immediately surrounding text. (Level AA) 377    vernacular of the immediately surrounding text. (Level AA)
378  378 
379  379 
380      Intent of this Success Criterion 380      Intent of this Success Criterion
381  381 
382The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that user agents can 382The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that user agents can
383correctly present content written in multiple languages. This makes it 383correctly present content written in multiple languages. This makes it
384possible for user agents and assistive technologies to present content 384possible for user agents and assistive technologies to present content
385according to the presentation and pronunciation rules for that language. 385according to the presentation and pronunciation rules for that language.
386This applies to graphical browsers as well as screen readers, braille 386This applies to graphical browsers as well as screen readers, braille
387displays, and other voice browsers. 387displays, and other voice browsers.
388  388 
389Both assistive technologies and conventional user agents can render text 389Both assistive technologies and conventional user agents can render text
390more accurately if the language of each passage of text is identified. 390more accurately if the language of each passage of text is identified.
391Screen readers can use the pronunciation rules of the language of the 391Screen readers can use the pronunciation rules of the language of the
392text. Visual browsers can display characters and scripts in appropriate 392text. Visual browsers can display characters and scripts in appropriate
393ways. This is especially important when switching between languages that 393ways. This is especially important when switching between languages that
394read from left to right and languages that read from right to left, or 394read from left to right and languages that read from right to left, or
395when text is rendered in a language that uses a different alphabet. 395when text is rendered in a language that uses a different alphabet.
396Users with disabilities who know all the languages used in the Web page 396Users with disabilities who know all the languages used in the Web page
397will be better able to understand the content when each passage is 397will be better able to understand the content when each passage is
398rendered appropriately. 398rendered appropriately.
399  399 
400When no other language has been specified for a phrase or passage of 400When no other language has been specified for a phrase or passage of
401text, its human language is the default human language of the Web page 401text, its human language is the default human language of the Web page
402(see Success Criterion 3.1.1). So the human language of all content in 402(see Success Criterion 3.1.1). So the human language of all content in
403single language documents can be programmatically determined. 403single language documents can be programmatically determined.
404  404 
405Individual words or phrases in one language can become part of another 405Individual words or phrases in one language can become part of another
406language. For example, "rendezvous" is a French word that has been 406language. For example, "rendezvous" is a French word that has been
407adopted in English, appears in English dictionaries, and is properly 407adopted in English, appears in English dictionaries, and is properly
408pronounced by English screen readers. Hence a passage of English text 408pronounced by English screen readers. Hence a passage of English text
409may contain the word "rendezvous" without specifying that its human 409may contain the word "rendezvous" without specifying that its human
410language is French and still satisfy this Success Criterion. Frequently, 410language is French and still satisfy this Success Criterion. Frequently,
411when the human language of text appears to be changing for a single 411when the human language of text appears to be changing for a single
412word, that word has become part of the language of the surrounding text. 412word, that word has become part of the language of the surrounding text.
413Because this is so common in some languages, single words should be 413Because this is so common in some languages, single words should be
414considered part of the language of the surrounding text unless it is 414considered part of the language of the surrounding text unless it is
415clear that a change in language was intended. If there is doubt whether 415clear that a change in language was intended. If there is doubt whether
416a change in language is intended, consider whether the word would be 416a change in language is intended, consider whether the word would be
417pronounced the same (except for accent or intonation) in the language of 417pronounced the same (except for accent or intonation) in the language of
418the immediately surrounding text. 418the immediately surrounding text.
419  419 
420Most professions require frequent use of technical terms which may 420Most professions require frequent use of technical terms which may
421originate from a foreign language. Such terms are usually not translated 421originate from a foreign language. Such terms are usually not translated
422to all languages. The universal nature of technical terms also 422to all languages. The universal nature of technical terms also
423facilitate communication between professionals. 423facilitate communication between professionals.
424  424 
425Some common examples of technical terms include: Homo sapiens, Alpha 425Some common examples of technical terms include: Homo sapiens, Alpha
426Centauri, hertz, and habeas corpus. 426Centauri, hertz, and habeas corpus.
427  427 
428Identifying changes in language is important for a number of reasons: 428Identifying changes in language is important for a number of reasons:
429  429 
430  * 430  *
431  431 
432    It allows braille translation software to follow changes in 432    It allows braille translation software to follow changes in
433    language, e.g., substitute control codes for accented characters, 433    language, e.g., substitute control codes for accented characters,
434    and insert control codes necessary to prevent erroneous creation of 434    and insert control codes necessary to prevent erroneous creation of
435    Grade 2 braille contractions. 435    Grade 2 braille contractions.
436  436 
437  * 437  *
438  438 
439    Speech synthesizers that support multiple languages will be able to 439    Speech synthesizers that support multiple languages will be able to
440    speak the text in the appropriate accent with proper pronunciation. 440    speak the text in the appropriate accent with proper pronunciation.
441    If changes are not marked, the synthesizer will try its best to 441    If changes are not marked, the synthesizer will try its best to
442    speak the words in the default language it works in. Thus, the 442    speak the words in the default language it works in. Thus, the
443    French word for car, "voiture" would be pronounced "voyture" by a 443    French word for car, "voiture" would be pronounced "voyture" by a
444    speech synthesizer that uses English as its default language. 444    speech synthesizer that uses English as its default language.
445  445 
446  * 446  *
447  447 
448    Marking changes in language can benefit future developments in 448    Marking changes in language can benefit future developments in
449    technology, for example users who are unable to translate between 449    technology, for example users who are unable to translate between
450    languages themselves will be able to use machines to translate 450    languages themselves will be able to use machines to translate
451    unfamiliar languages. 451    unfamiliar languages.
452  452

456    definitions using a dictionary. 456    definitions using a dictionary.

487 1. 487 1.
488  488 
489    *A German phrase in an English sentence. * 489    *A German phrase in an English sentence. *
490  490 
491    In the sentence, "He maintained that the DDR (German Democratic 491    In the sentence, "He maintained that the DDR (German Democratic
492    Republic) was just a 'Treppenwitz der Weltgeschichte'," the German 492    Republic) was just a 'Treppenwitz der Weltgeschichte'," the German
493    phrase 'Treppenwitz der Weltgeschichte' is marked as German. 493    phrase 'Treppenwitz der Weltgeschichte' is marked as German.
494    Depending on the markup language, English may either be marked as 494    Depending on the markup language, English may either be marked as
495    the language for the entire document except where specified, or 495    the language for the entire document except where specified, or
496    marked at the paragraph level. When a screen reader encounters the 496    marked at the paragraph level. When a screen reader encounters the
497    German phrase, it changes pronunciation rules from English to German 497    German phrase, it changes pronunciation rules from English to German
498    to pronounce the word correctly. 498    to pronounce the word correctly.
499  499 
500 2. 500 2.
501  501 
502    *Alternative language links* 502    *Alternative language links*
503  503 
504    An HTML Web page includes links to versions of the page in other 504    An HTML Web page includes links to versions of the page in other
505    languages (e.g., Deutsch, Français, Nederlands, Castellano, etc.). 505    languages (e.g., Deutsch, Français, Nederlands, Castellano, etc.).
506    The text of each link is the name of the language, in that language. 506    The text of each link is the name of the language, in that language.
507    The language of each link is indicated via a |lang| attribute. 507    The language of each link is indicated via a |lang| attribute.
508  508

514    surrounding text in the following excerpt, "À l'occasion de 514    surrounding text in the following excerpt, "À l'occasion de

703    so that the definition search will find the intended definitions 703    so that the definition search will find the intended definitions
704    instead of displaying definitions from other sources in the 704    instead of displaying definitions from other sources in the
705    "cascade." (The "cascade" lists the dictionaries and other reference 705    "cascade." (The "cascade" lists the dictionaries and other reference
706    materials in the order most likely to bring up the right definition. 706    materials in the order most likely to bring up the right definition.
707    This controls the order to follow when searching for definitions.) 707    This controls the order to follow when searching for definitions.)

754    <http://www.freelang.com/> (in English, Spanish and French!) and 754    <http://www.freelang.com/> (in English, Spanish and French!) and
755    many other places. 755    many other places.

760Each numbered item in this section represents a technique or combination 760Each numbered item in this section represents a technique or combination
761of techniques that the WCAG Working Group deems sufficient for meeting 761of techniques that the WCAG Working Group deems sufficient for meeting
762this Success Criterion. The techniques listed only satisfy the Success 762this Success Criterion. The techniques listed only satisfy the Success
763Criterion if all of the WCAG 2.0 conformance requirements 763Criterion if all of the WCAG 2.0 conformance requirements
764<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#conformance-reqs> have 764<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#conformance-reqs> have
765been met. 765been met.

773situation. 773situation.

896techniques should be considered in order to make content more 896techniques should be considered in order to make content more
897accessible. Not all techniques can be used or would be effective in all 897accessible. Not all techniques can be used or would be effective in all
898situations. 898situations.

936        Common Failures for SC 3.1.3 936        Common Failures for SC 3.1.3
937  937 
938The following are common mistakes that are considered failures of 938The following are common mistakes that are considered failures of
939Success Criterion 3.1.3 by the WCAG Working Group. 939Success Criterion 3.1.3 by the WCAG Working Group.
940  940 
941(No failures currently documented) 941(No failures currently documented)
942  942 
943  943 
944      Key Terms 944      Key Terms
945  945 
946idiom 946idiom
947  947 
948    phrase whose meaning cannot be deduced from the meaning of the 948    phrase whose meaning cannot be deduced from the meaning of the
949    individual words and the specific words cannot be changed without 949    individual words and the specific words cannot be changed without
950    losing the meaning 950    losing the meaning
951  951 
952    /Note: /idioms cannot be translated directly, word for word, without 952    /Note: /idioms cannot be translated directly, word for word, without
953    losing their (cultural or language-dependent) meaning. 953    losing their (cultural or language-dependent) meaning.
954  954 
955    /Example 1: /In English, "spilling the beans" means "revealing a 955    /Example 1: /In English, "spilling the beans" means "revealing a
956    secret." However, "knocking over the beans" or "spilling the 956    secret." However, "knocking over the beans" or "spilling the
957    vegetables" does not mean the same thing. 957    vegetables" does not mean the same thing.
958  958 
959    /Example 2: /In Japanese, the phrase "さじを投げる" literally 959    /Example 2: /In Japanese, the phrase "さじを投げる" literally
960    translates into "he throws a spoon," but it means that there is 960    translates into "he throws a spoon," but it means that there is
961    nothing he can do and finally he gives up. 961    nothing he can do and finally he gives up.
962  962 
963    /Example 3: /In Dutch, "Hij ging met de kippen op stok" literally 963    /Example 3: /In Dutch, "Hij ging met de kippen op stok" literally
964    translates into "He went to roost with the chickens," but it means 964    translates into "He went to roost with the chickens," but it means
965    that he went to bed early. 965    that he went to bed early.
966  966 
967jargon 967jargon
968  968 
969    words used in a particular way by people in a particular field 969    words used in a particular way by people in a particular field
970  970 
971    /Example: /The word StickyKeys is jargon from the field of assistive 971    /Example: /The word StickyKeys is jargon from the field of assistive
972    technology/accessibility. 972    technology/accessibility.
973  973 
974mechanism 974mechanism
975  975 
976    process <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#processdef> 976    process <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#processdef>
977    or technique for achieving a result 977    or technique for achieving a result
978  978 
979    /Note 1: /The mechanism may be explicitly provided in the content, 979    /Note 1: /The mechanism may be explicitly provided in the content,
980    or may be relied upon 980    or may be relied upon
981    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#reliedupondef> to be 981    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#reliedupondef> to be
982    provided by either the platform or by user agents 982    provided by either the platform or by user agents
983    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#useragentdef>, 983    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#useragentdef>,
984    including assistive technologies 984    including assistive technologies
985    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#atdef>. 985    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#atdef>.
986  986 
987    /Note 2: /The mechanism needs to meet all success criteria for the 987    /Note 2: /The mechanism needs to meet all success criteria for the
988    conformance level claimed. 988    conformance level claimed.
989  989 
990used in an unusual or restricted way 990used in an unusual or restricted way
991  991 
992    words used in such a way that requires users to know exactly which 992    words used in such a way that requires users to know exactly which
993    definition to apply in order to understand the content correctly 993    definition to apply in order to understand the content correctly
994  994 
995    /Example: /The term "gig" means something different if it occurs in 995    /Example: /The term "gig" means something different if it occurs in
996    a discussion of music concerts than it does in article about 996    a discussion of music concerts than it does in article about
997    computer hard drive space, but the appropriate definition can be 997    computer hard drive space, but the appropriate definition can be
998    determined from context. By contrast, the word "text" is used in a 998    determined from context. By contrast, the word "text" is used in a
999    very specific way in WCAG 2.0, so a definition is supplied in the 999    very specific way in WCAG 2.0, so a definition is supplied in the
1000    glossary. 1000    glossary.

1010    Abbreviations:* A mechanism 1010    Abbreviations:* A mechanism
1011    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#mechanismdef> for 1011    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#mechanismdef> for
1012    identifying the expanded form or meaning of abbreviations 1012    identifying the expanded form or meaning of abbreviations
1013    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#abbreviationsdef> is 1013    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#abbreviationsdef> is
1014    available. (Level AAA) 1014    available. (Level AAA)
1015  1015 
1016  1016 
1017      Intent of this Success Criterion 1017      Intent of this Success Criterion
1018  1018 
1019The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that users can access 1019The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that users can access
1020the expanded form of abbreviations. 1020the expanded form of abbreviations.
1021  1021 
1022  1022 
1023        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 3.1.4 1023        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 3.1.4
1024  1024 
1025This Success Criterion may help people who: 1025This Success Criterion may help people who:
1026  1026 
1027  * 1027  *
1028  1028 
1029    have difficulty decoding words; 1029    have difficulty decoding words;
1030  1030 
1031  * 1031  *
1032  1032 
1033    rely on screen magnifiers (magnification may reduce contextual cues); 1033    rely on screen magnifiers (magnification may reduce contextual cues);
1034  1034 
1035  * 1035  *
1036  1036 
1037    have limited memory; 1037    have limited memory;
1038  1038 
1039  * 1039  *
1040  1040 
1041    have difficulty using context to aid understanding. 1041    have difficulty using context to aid understanding.
1042  1042 
1043Abbreviations may confuse some readers in different ways: 1043Abbreviations may confuse some readers in different ways:
1044  1044 
1045  * 1045  *
1046  1046 
1047    Some abbreviations do not look like normal words and cannot be 1047    Some abbreviations do not look like normal words and cannot be
1048    pronounced according to the usual rules of the language. For 1048    pronounced according to the usual rules of the language. For
1049    example, the English word "room" is abbreviated as "rm," which does 1049    example, the English word "room" is abbreviated as "rm," which does
1050    not correspond to any English word or phoneme. The user has to know 1050    not correspond to any English word or phoneme. The user has to know
1051    that "rm" is an abbreviation for the word "room" in order to say it 1051    that "rm" is an abbreviation for the word "room" in order to say it
1052    correctly. 1052    correctly.
1053  1053 
1054  * 1054  *
1055  1055 
1056    Sometimes, the same abbreviation means different things in different 1056    Sometimes, the same abbreviation means different things in different
1057    contexts. For example, in the English sentence "Dr. Johnson lives on 1057    contexts. For example, in the English sentence "Dr. Johnson lives on
1058    Boswell Dr.," the first "Dr." is an abbreviation for "Doctor" and 1058    Boswell Dr.," the first "Dr." is an abbreviation for "Doctor" and
1059    the second instance is an abbreviation for the word "Drive" (a word 1059    the second instance is an abbreviation for the word "Drive" (a word
1060    that means "street"). Users must be able to understand the context 1060    that means "street"). Users must be able to understand the context
1061    in order to know what the abbreviations mean. 1061    in order to know what the abbreviations mean.
1062  1062 
1063  * 1063  *
1064  1064 
1065    Some acronyms spell common words but are used in different ways. For 1065    Some acronyms spell common words but are used in different ways. For
1066    example, "JAWS" is an acronym for a screen reader whose full name is 1066    example, "JAWS" is an acronym for a screen reader whose full name is
1067    "Job Access with Speech." It is also a common English word referring 1067    "Job Access with Speech." It is also a common English word referring
1068    to the part of the mouth that holds the teeth. The acronym is used 1068    to the part of the mouth that holds the teeth. The acronym is used
1069    differently than the common word. 1069    differently than the common word.
1070  1070 
1071  * 1071  *
1072  1072 
1073    Some acronyms sound like common words but are spelled differently. 1073    Some acronyms sound like common words but are spelled differently.
1074    For example, the acronym for Synchronized Multimedia Integration 1074    For example, the acronym for Synchronized Multimedia Integration
1075    Language, S M I L, is pronounced like the English word "smile." 1075    Language, S M I L, is pronounced like the English word "smile."
1076  1076 
1077It would also help people with visual disabilities who: 1077It would also help people with visual disabilities who:
1078  1078 
1079  * 1079  *
1080  1080 
1081    Lose context when zoomed-in with a screen magnifier 1081    Lose context when zoomed-in with a screen magnifier
1082  1082 
1083  1083 
1084      Examples of Success Criterion 3.1.4 1084      Examples of Success Criterion 3.1.4
1085  1085 
1086  * 1086  *
1087  1087 
1088    *An abbreviation whose expansion is provided the first time the 1088    *An abbreviation whose expansion is provided the first time the
1089    abbreviation appears in the content.* 1089    abbreviation appears in the content.*
1090  1090 
1091    The name, "World Wide Web Consortium," appears as the first heading 1091    The name, "World Wide Web Consortium," appears as the first heading
1092    on the organization's home page. The abbreviation, "W3C," is 1092    on the organization's home page. The abbreviation, "W3C," is
1093    enclosed in parentheses in the same heading. 1093    enclosed in parentheses in the same heading.
1094  1094 
1095  * 1095  *
1096  1096 
1097    *A dictionary search form.* 1097    *A dictionary search form.*
1098  1098 
1099    A Web site includes a search form provided by an on-line acronym 1099    A Web site includes a search form provided by an on-line acronym
1100    service. Users enter an acronym and the form returns a list of 1100    service. Users enter an acronym and the form returns a list of
1101    possible expansions from the sources that it searched. 1101    possible expansions from the sources that it searched.
1102  1102 
1103  * 1103  *
1104  1104 
1105    *A medical Web site.* 1105    *A medical Web site.*
1106  1106 
1107    A medical Web site provides information for both doctors and 1107    A medical Web site provides information for both doctors and
1108    patients. The site includes a set of cascading dictionaries; a very 1108    patients. The site includes a set of cascading dictionaries; a very
1109    specialized medical dictionary is first, followed by a second 1109    specialized medical dictionary is first, followed by a second
1110    medical dictionary for the general public. The cascade also includes 1110    medical dictionary for the general public. The cascade also includes
1111    a list of acronyms and abbreviations that are unique to the site, 1111    a list of acronyms and abbreviations that are unique to the site,
1112    and finally there is a standard dictionary as well. The standard 1112    and finally there is a standard dictionary as well. The standard
1113    dictionary at the end of the list provides definitions for most 1113    dictionary at the end of the list provides definitions for most
1114    words in the text. The specialized medical dictionary yields 1114    words in the text. The specialized medical dictionary yields
1115    definitions of unusual medical terms. Definitions for words that 1115    definitions of unusual medical terms. Definitions for words that
1116    appear in more than one dictionary are listed in the order of the 1116    appear in more than one dictionary are listed in the order of the
1117    cascade. The meaning of acronyms and abbreviations is provided by 1117    cascade. The meaning of acronyms and abbreviations is provided by
1118    the list of acronyms and abbreviations. 1118    the list of acronyms and abbreviations.
1119  1119 
1120  * 1120  *
1121  1121 
1122    *Expanded forms of Abbreviations. * 1122    *Expanded forms of Abbreviations. *
1123  1123 
1124    The expanded form of each abbreviation is available in a 1124    The expanded form of each abbreviation is available in a
1125    programmatically determinable manner. User agents that speak the 1125    programmatically determinable manner. User agents that speak the
1126    text can use the expanded form to announce the abbreviation. Other 1126    text can use the expanded form to announce the abbreviation. Other
1127    user agents might make the expanded form available as a tooltip or 1127    user agents might make the expanded form available as a tooltip or
1128    as contextual help for the abbreviation. 1128    as contextual help for the abbreviation.

1308    /Note 1: /This includes initialisms and acronyms where: 1308    /Note 1: /This includes initialisms and acronyms where:
1309  1309

1311  1311 
1312        *initialisms* are shortened forms of a name or phrase made from 1312        *initialisms* are shortened forms of a name or phrase made from
1313        the initial letters of words or syllables contained in that name 1313        the initial letters of words or syllables contained in that name
1314        or phrase 1314        or phrase
1315  1315 
1316        /Note 1: /Not defined in all languages. 1316        /Note 1: /Not defined in all languages.
1317  1317 
1318        /Example 1: /SNCF is a French initialism that contains the 1318        /Example 1: /SNCF is a French initialism that contains the
1319        initial letters of the Société Nationale des Chemins de Fer, the 1319        initial letters of the Société Nationale des Chemins de Fer, the
1320        French national railroad. 1320        French national railroad.
1321  1321 
1322        /Example 2: /ESP is an initialism for extrasensory perception. 1322        /Example 2: /ESP is an initialism for extrasensory perception.
1323  1323 
1324     2. 1324     2.
1325  1325 
1326        *acronyms* are abbreviated forms made from the initial letters 1326        *acronyms* are abbreviated forms made from the initial letters
1327        or parts of other words (in a name or phrase) which may be 1327        or parts of other words (in a name or phrase) which may be
1328        pronounced as a word 1328        pronounced as a word
1329  1329 
1330        /Example: /NOAA is an acronym made from the initial letters of 1330        /Example: /NOAA is an acronym made from the initial letters of
1331        the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in the 1331        the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in the
1332        United States. 1332        United States.
1333  1333 
1334    /Note 2: /Some companies have adopted what used to be an initialism 1334    /Note 2: /Some companies have adopted what used to be an initialism
1335    as their company name. In these cases, the new name of the company 1335    as their company name. In these cases, the new name of the company
1336    is the letters (for example, Ecma) and the word is no longer 1336    is the letters (for example, Ecma) and the word is no longer
1337    considered an abbreviation. 1337    considered an abbreviation.

1359    Understanding SC 3.1.5 1359    Understanding SC 3.1.5
1360  1360 
1361    *3.1.5 1361    *3.1.5
1362    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#meaning-supplements> 1362    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#meaning-supplements>

1364    than the lower secondary education level 1364    than the lower secondary education level
1365    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#lowseceddef> after 1365    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#lowseceddef> after
1366    removal of proper names and titles, supplemental content 1366    removal of proper names and titles, supplemental content
1367    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#suppcontentdef>, or 1367    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#suppcontentdef>, or
1368    a version that does not require reading ability more advanced than 1368    a version that does not require reading ability more advanced than
1369    the lower secondary education level, is available. (Level AAA) 1369    the lower secondary education level, is available. (Level AAA)
1370  1370 
1371  1371 
1372      Intent of this Success Criterion 1372      Intent of this Success Criterion
1373  1373 
1374Content should be written as clearly and simply as possible. The intent 1374Content should be written as clearly and simply as possible. The intent
1375of this Success Criterion is: 1375of this Success Criterion is:
1376  1376 
1377  * 1377  *
1378  1378 
1379    to ensure that additional content is available to aid the 1379    to ensure that additional content is available to aid the
1380    understanding of difficult or complex text; 1380    understanding of difficult or complex text;
1381  1381 
1382  * 1382  *
1383  1383 
1384    to establish a testable measure indicating when such additional 1384    to establish a testable measure indicating when such additional
1385    content is required. 1385    content is required.
1386  1386 
1387This Success Criterion helps people with reading disabilities while also 1387This Success Criterion helps people with reading disabilities while also
1388allowing authors to publish difficult or complex Web content. Text 1388allowing authors to publish difficult or complex Web content. Text
1389difficulty is described in terms of the level of education required to 1389difficulty is described in terms of the level of education required to
1390read the text. Education levels are defined according to the 1390read the text. Education levels are defined according to the
1391International Standard Classification of Education [UNESCO] <#UNESCO>, 1391International Standard Classification of Education [UNESCO] <#UNESCO>,
1392which was created to allow international comparison among systems of 1392which was created to allow international comparison among systems of
1393education. 1393education.
1394  1394 
1395Difficult or complex text may be appropriate for most members of the 1395Difficult or complex text may be appropriate for most members of the
1396intended audience (that is, most of the people for whom the content has 1396intended audience (that is, most of the people for whom the content has
1397been created). But there are people with disabilities, including reading 1397been created). But there are people with disabilities, including reading
1398disabilities, even among highly educated users with specialized 1398disabilities, even among highly educated users with specialized
1399knowledge of the subject matter. It may be possible to accommodate these 1399knowledge of the subject matter. It may be possible to accommodate these
1400users by making the text more readable. If the text cannot be made more 1400users by making the text more readable. If the text cannot be made more
1401readable, then supplemental content is needed. Supplemental content is 1401readable, then supplemental content is needed. Supplemental content is
1402required when text demands reading ability more advanced than the lower 1402required when text demands reading ability more advanced than the lower
1403secondary education level—that is, more than nine years of school. Such 1403secondary education level—that is, more than nine years of school. Such
1404text presents severe obstacles to people with reading disabilities and 1404text presents severe obstacles to people with reading disabilities and
1405is considered difficult even for people without disabilities who have 1405is considered difficult even for people without disabilities who have
1406completed upper secondary education. 1406completed upper secondary education.
1407  1407 
1408Reading disabilities such as dyslexia make it difficult to recognize 1408Reading disabilities such as dyslexia make it difficult to recognize
1409written or printed words and associate them with the correct sounds. 1409written or printed words and associate them with the correct sounds.
1410This is called "decoding" the text. Decoding must be automatic in order 1410This is called "decoding" the text. Decoding must be automatic in order
1411for people to read fluently. The act of decoding text word by word 1411for people to read fluently. The act of decoding text word by word
1412consumes much of the mental energy that most people are able to use for 1412consumes much of the mental energy that most people are able to use for
1413understanding what they read. Text that uses short, common words and 1413understanding what they read. Text that uses short, common words and
1414short sentences is easier to decode and usually requires less advanced 1414short sentences is easier to decode and usually requires less advanced
1415reading ability than text that uses long sentences and long or 1415reading ability than text that uses long sentences and long or
1416unfamiliar words. 1416unfamiliar words.
1417  1417 
1418The education level required to read text content (also called 1418The education level required to read text content (also called
1419"readability") is measured by analyzing selected passages of text from 1419"readability") is measured by analyzing selected passages of text from
1420the Web page. If the Web page includes text written for different 1420the Web page. If the Web page includes text written for different
1421purposes or different styles are used, the selected passages include 1421purposes or different styles are used, the selected passages include
1422samples of the types of content in the Web page and the different styles 1422samples of the types of content in the Web page and the different styles
1423in which the content is written. (In many cases, the Web page contains 1423in which the content is written. (In many cases, the Web page contains
1424only one kind of text content—e.g., technical documentation, a legal 1424only one kind of text content—e.g., technical documentation, a legal
1425notice, marketing material, etc.—and all the content uses the same style.) 1425notice, marketing material, etc.—and all the content uses the same style.)

1446When a Web page contains multiple languages, a readability result should 1446When a Web page contains multiple languages, a readability result should
1447be calculated for each language that constitutes at least 5% of the 1447be calculated for each language that constitutes at least 5% of the
1448content and that is used in full sentences or paragraphs (not just 1448content and that is used in full sentences or paragraphs (not just
1449individual words or phrases). The overall readability of the page should 1449individual words or phrases). The overall readability of the page should
1450be judged on the language that yields the worst readability results. 1450be judged on the language that yields the worst readability results.
1451  1451 
1452The readability of content may also be determined by applying a 1452The readability of content may also be determined by applying a
1453readability formula to the selected passage. Many (though not all) 1453readability formula to the selected passage. Many (though not all)
1454readability formulas base their calculations on passages of 100 words. 1454readability formulas base their calculations on passages of 100 words.
1455Such formulas have been developed for many languages. The number of 1455Such formulas have been developed for many languages. The number of
1456words in the passage is counted and the length of the words is 1456words in the passage is counted and the length of the words is
1457determined by counting either the number of syllables or the number of 1457determined by counting either the number of syllables or the number of
1458characters. Most readability formulas also count the number and length 1458characters. Most readability formulas also count the number and length
1459of sentences. The average length of words and sentences in the content 1459of sentences. The average length of words and sentences in the content
1460is then used to calculate a readability score. (Some languages, such as 1460is then used to calculate a readability score. (Some languages, such as
1461Japanese, may include multiple scripts within the same passage. 1461Japanese, may include multiple scripts within the same passage.
1462Readability formulas for these languages may use the number and length 1462Readability formulas for these languages may use the number and length
1463of such "runs" in their calculations.) The result may be presented as a 1463of such "runs" in their calculations.) The result may be presented as a
1464number (for example, on a scale from 0-100) or as a grade level. These 1464number (for example, on a scale from 0-100) or as a grade level. These
1465results can then be interpreted using the education levels described in 1465results can then be interpreted using the education levels described in
1466the International Standard Classification of Education. Readability 1466the International Standard Classification of Education. Readability
1467formulas are available for at least some languages when running the 1467formulas are available for at least some languages when running the

1718/Note: /Different sites may address this Success Criterion in different 1718/Note: /Different sites may address this Success Criterion in different
1719ways. An audio version of the content may be helpful to some users. For 1719ways. An audio version of the content may be helpful to some users. For
1720some people who are deaf, a sign language version of the page may be 1720some people who are deaf, a sign language version of the page may be
1721easier to understand than a written language version since sign language 1721easier to understand than a written language version since sign language
1722may be their first language. Some sites may decide to do both or other 1722may be their first language. Some sites may decide to do both or other
1723combinations. No technique will help all users who have difficulty. So 1723combinations. No technique will help all users who have difficulty. So
1724different techniques are provided as sufficient techniques here for 1724different techniques are provided as sufficient techniques here for
1725authors trying to make their sites more accessible. Any numbered 1725authors trying to make their sites more accessible. Any numbered
1726technique or combination above can be used by a particular site and it 1726technique or combination above can be used by a particular site and it
1727is considered sufficient by the Working Group. 1727is considered sufficient by the Working Group.

1879    available for identifying specific pronunciation of words where 1879    available for identifying specific pronunciation of words where
1880    meaning of the words, in context, is ambiguous without knowing the 1880    meaning of the words, in context, is ambiguous without knowing the
1881    pronunciation. (Level AAA) 1881    pronunciation. (Level AAA)
1882  1882 
1883  1883 
1884      Intent of this Success Criterion 1884      Intent of this Success Criterion
1885  1885 
1886The intent of this Success Criterion is to help people who are blind, 1886The intent of this Success Criterion is to help people who are blind,
1887people who have low vision, and people with reading disabilities to 1887people who have low vision, and people with reading disabilities to
1888understand content in cases where meaning depends on pronunciation. 1888understand content in cases where meaning depends on pronunciation.
1889Often words or characters have different meanings, each with its own 1889Often words or characters have different meanings, each with its own
1890pronunciation. The meaning of such words or characters can usually be 1890pronunciation. The meaning of such words or characters can usually be
1891determined from the context of the sentence. However, for more complex 1891determined from the context of the sentence. However, for more complex
1892or ambiguous sentences, or for some languages, the meaning of the word 1892or ambiguous sentences, or for some languages, the meaning of the word
1893cannot be easily determined or determined at all without knowing the 1893cannot be easily determined or determined at all without knowing the
1894pronunciation. When the sentence is read aloud and the screen reader 1894pronunciation. When the sentence is read aloud and the screen reader
1895reads the word using the wrong pronunciation, it can be even more 1895reads the word using the wrong pronunciation, it can be even more
1896difficult to understand than when read visually. When words are 1896difficult to understand than when read visually. When words are
1897ambiguous or indeterminate unless the pronunciation is known, then 1897ambiguous or indeterminate unless the pronunciation is known, then
1898providing some means of determining the pronunciation is needed. 1898providing some means of determining the pronunciation is needed.
1899  1899 
1900For example, in the English language heteronyms are words that are 1900For example, in the English language heteronyms are words that are
1901spelled the same but have different pronunciations and meanings, such as 1901spelled the same but have different pronunciations and meanings, such as
1902the words desert (abandon) and desert (arid region). If the proper 1902the words desert (abandon) and desert (arid region). If the proper
1903pronunciation can be determined from the context of the sentence, then 1903pronunciation can be determined from the context of the sentence, then
1904nothing is required. If it cannot then some mechanism for determining 1904nothing is required. If it cannot then some mechanism for determining
1905the proper pronunciation would be required. Additionally, in some 1905the proper pronunciation would be required. Additionally, in some
1906languages certain characters can be pronounced in different ways. In 1906languages certain characters can be pronounced in different ways. In
1907Japanese, for example, there are characters like Han characters(Kanji) 1907Japanese, for example, there are characters like Han characters(Kanji)
1908that have multiple pronunciations. Screen readers may speak the 1908that have multiple pronunciations. Screen readers may speak the
1909characters incorrectly without the information on pronunciation. When 1909characters incorrectly without the information on pronunciation. When
1910read incorrectly, the content will not make sense to users. 1910read incorrectly, the content will not make sense to users.

1934    *Giving the reading of a person's name.* 1934    *Giving the reading of a person's name.*
1935  1935 
1936    Web content in Japanese provides kana (Japanese phonetic syllabary 1936    Web content in Japanese provides kana (Japanese phonetic syllabary
1937    characters) written next to Han characters (Kanji) show the 1937    characters) written next to Han characters (Kanji) show the
1938    pronunciation of a person's name. The kana is provided to users in 1938    pronunciation of a person's name. The kana is provided to users in
1939    parentheses right after the word. Giving the reading of the words 1939    parentheses right after the word. Giving the reading of the words
1940    written in Han characters (Kanji) allows both sighted users and 1940    written in Han characters (Kanji) allows both sighted users and
1941    screen readers to read/pronounce the words correctly. Note that 1941    screen readers to read/pronounce the words correctly. Note that
1942    screen readers will speak the word twice: the Han characters (Kanji) 1942    screen readers will speak the word twice: the Han characters (Kanji)
1943    that can be pronounced in a wrong way are read first and then kana 1943    that can be pronounced in a wrong way are read first and then kana
1944    is spoken in order to provide the correct reading. 1944    is spoken in order to provide the correct reading.

1959    without knowing the correct pronunciation. Each word is linked to a 1959    without knowing the correct pronunciation. Each word is linked to a
1960    sound file that gives the correct pronunciation. Users can select 1960    sound file that gives the correct pronunciation. Users can select
1961    these links to find out how to pronounce the words. 1961    these links to find out how to pronounce the words.

2093  2093 
2094  2094 
2095      Intent of Guideline 3.2 2095      Intent of Guideline 3.2
2096  2096 
2097The intent of this Guideline is to help users with disabilities by 2097The intent of this Guideline is to help users with disabilities by
2098presenting content in a predictable order from Web page to Web page and 2098presenting content in a predictable order from Web page to Web page and
2099by making the behavior of functional and interactive components 2099by making the behavior of functional and interactive components
2100predictable. It is difficult for some users to form an overview of the 2100predictable. It is difficult for some users to form an overview of the
2101Web page: screen readers present content as a one-dimensional stream of 2101Web page: screen readers present content as a one-dimensional stream of
2102synthetic speech that makes it difficult to understand spatial 2102synthetic speech that makes it difficult to understand spatial
2103relationships. Users with cognitive limitations may become confused if 2103relationships. Users with cognitive limitations may become confused if
2104components appear in different places on different pages. 2104components appear in different places on different pages.
2105  2105 
2106For example, people who use screen magnifiers see only part of the 2106For example, people who use screen magnifiers see only part of the
2107screen at any point in time; a consistent layout makes it easier for 2107screen at any point in time; a consistent layout makes it easier for
2108them to find navigation bars and other components. Placing repeated 2108them to find navigation bars and other components. Placing repeated
2109components in the same relative order within a set of Web pages allows 2109components in the same relative order within a set of Web pages allows
2110users with reading disabilities to focus on an area of the screen rather 2110users with reading disabilities to focus on an area of the screen rather
2111than spending additional time decoding the text of each link. Users with 2111than spending additional time decoding the text of each link. Users with
2112limited use of their hands can more easily determine how to complete 2112limited use of their hands can more easily determine how to complete
2113their tasks using the fewest keystrokes. 2113their tasks using the fewest keystrokes.

2120Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for 2120Criterion (listed below). If there are techniques, however, for
2121addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success 2121addressing this guideline that do not fall under any of the success
2122criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or 2122criteria, they are listed here. These techniques are not required or

2124of Web content more accessible to more people. 2124of Web content more accessible to more people.

2137    change of context 2137    change of context

2145predictable as visitors navigate their way through a document. Any 2145predictable as visitors navigate their way through a document. Any
2146component that is able to trigger an event when it receives focus must 2146component that is able to trigger an event when it receives focus must
2147not change the context. Examples of changing context when a component 2147not change the context. Examples of changing context when a component
2148receives focus include, but are not limited to: 2148receives focus include, but are not limited to:

2163Focus may be moved to a control either via the keyboard (e.g. tabbing to 2163Focus may be moved to a control either via the keyboard (e.g. tabbing to
2164a control) or the mouse (e.g. clicking on a text field). Moving the 2164a control) or the mouse (e.g. clicking on a text field). Moving the
2165mouse over a control does not move the focus unless scripting implements 2165mouse over a control does not move the focus unless scripting implements
2166this behavior. Note that for some types of controls, clicking on a 2166this behavior. Note that for some types of controls, clicking on a

2185  2185 
2186    A dropdown menu on a page allows users to choose between jump 2186    A dropdown menu on a page allows users to choose between jump
2187    destinations. If the person uses the keyboard to move down to a 2187    destinations. If the person uses the keyboard to move down to a
2188    choice and activates it (with a spacebar or enter key) it will jump 2188    choice and activates it (with a spacebar or enter key) it will jump
2189    to a new page. However, if the person moves down to a choice and 2189    to a new page. However, if the person moves down to a choice and
2190    either hits the escape or the tab key to move out of the pulldown 2190    either hits the escape or the tab key to move out of the pulldown
2191    menu – it does not jump to a new screen as the focus shifts out of 2191    menu – it does not jump to a new screen as the focus shifts out of
2192    the dropdown menu. 2192    the dropdown menu.

2199    field and providing options opens. As a keyboard user tabs through 2199    field and providing options opens. As a keyboard user tabs through
2200    the Web page, the dialog opens, moving the keyboard focus away from 2200    the Web page, the dialog opens, moving the keyboard focus away from
2201    the control every time the user attempts to tab past the field. 2201    the control every time the user attempts to tab past the field.

2334      Intent of this Success Criterion 2334      Intent of this Success Criterion
2335  2335 
2336The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that entering data or 2336The intent of this Success Criterion is to ensure that entering data or
2337selecting a form control has predictable effects. Changing the setting 2337selecting a form control has predictable effects. Changing the setting
2338of any user interface component is changing some state in the control 2338of any user interface component is changing some state in the control
2339that will persist when the user is no longer interacting with it. So 2339that will persist when the user is no longer interacting with it. So
2340checking a checkbox or entering text into a text field changes its 2340checking a checkbox or entering text into a text field changes its
2341setting, but activating a link or a button does not. Changes in context 2341setting, but activating a link or a button does not. Changes in context
2342can confuse users who do not easily perceive the change or are easily 2342can confuse users who do not easily perceive the change or are easily
2343distracted by changes. Changes of context are appropriate only when it 2343distracted by changes. Changes of context are appropriate only when it
2344is clear that such a change will happen in response to the user's action. 2344is clear that such a change will happen in response to the user's action.
2345  2345 
2346/Note: /This Success Criterion covers changes in context due to changing 2346/Note: /This Success Criterion covers changes in context due to changing
2347the setting of a control. Clicking on links or tabs in a tab control is 2347the setting of a control. Clicking on links or tabs in a tab control is
2348activating the control, not changing the setting of that control. 2348activating the control, not changing the setting of that control.

2353  * 2353  *
2354  2354 
2355    This Success Criterion helps users with disabilities by making 2355    This Success Criterion helps users with disabilities by making
2356    interactive content more predictable. Unexpected changes of context 2356    interactive content more predictable. Unexpected changes of context
2357    can be so disorienting for users with visual disabilities or 2357    can be so disorienting for users with visual disabilities or
2358    cognitive limitations that they are unable to use the content. 2358    cognitive limitations that they are unable to use the content.
2359  2359

2363    likely to become disoriented while navigating a site. For example: 2363    likely to become disoriented while navigating a site. For example:
2364  2364 
2365      o 2365      o
2366  2366 
2367        Individuals who are blind or have low vision may have difficulty 2367        Individuals who are blind or have low vision may have difficulty
2368        knowing when a visual context change has occurred, such as a new 2368        knowing when a visual context change has occurred, such as a new
2369        window popping up. In this case, warning users of context 2369        window popping up. In this case, warning users of context
2370        changes in advance minimizes confusion when the user discovers 2370        changes in advance minimizes confusion when the user discovers
2371        that the back button no longer behaves as expected. 2371        that the back button no longer behaves as expected.

2384  2384 
2385    A form is provided for creating calendar entries in a Web based 2385    A form is provided for creating calendar entries in a Web based
2386    calendaring and scheduling application. Along with the standard 2386    calendaring and scheduling application. Along with the standard
2387    fields for subject, time and location, there is a set of radio 2387    fields for subject, time and location, there is a set of radio
2388    buttons to select the type of calendar entry to create. The calendar 2388    buttons to select the type of calendar entry to create. The calendar
2389    entry type can be meeting, appointment or reminder. If the user 2389    entry type can be meeting, appointment or reminder. If the user
2390    selects the radio for meeting, additional fields are displayed on 2390    selects the radio for meeting, additional fields are displayed on
2391    the page for entering the meeting participants. Different fields 2391    the page for entering the meeting participants. Different fields
2392    appear if the reminder button is chosen. Because only parts of the 2392    appear if the reminder button is chosen. Because only parts of the
2393    entry change and the overall structure remains the same the basic 2393    entry change and the overall structure remains the same the basic
2394    context remains for the user. 2394    context remains for the user.
2395  2395 
2396  * 2396  *
2397  2397 
2398    A form contains fields representing US phone numbers. All of the 2398    A form contains fields representing US phone numbers. All of the
2399    numbers have a three digit area code followed by a three digit 2399    numbers have a three digit area code followed by a three digit
2400    prefix and finally a four digit number, and each part of the phone 2400    prefix and finally a four digit number, and each part of the phone
2401    number is entered into a separate field. When the user completes the 2401    number is entered into a separate field. When the user completes the
2402    entry of one field and enter the first digit of the next field, the 2402    entry of one field and enter the first digit of the next field, the
2403    focus automatically moves to the next field of the phone number. 2403    focus automatically moves to the next field of the phone number.
2404    This behavior of phone fields is described for the user at the 2404    This behavior of phone fields is described for the user at the
2405    beginning of the form. 2405    beginning of the form.

2419this Success Criterion. The techniques listed only satisfy the Success 2419this Success Criterion. The techniques listed only satisfy the Success
2420Criterion if all of the WCAG 2.0 conformance requirements 2420Criterion if all of the WCAG 2.0 conformance requirements
2421<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#conformance-reqs> have 2421<http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#conformance-reqs> have
2422been met. 2422been met.

2552    /Note: /A change of content is not always a change of context. 2552    /Note: /A change of content is not always a change of context.
2553    Changes in content, such as an expanding outline, dynamic menu, or a 2553    Changes in content, such as an expanding outline, dynamic menu, or a
2554    tab control do not necessarily change the context, unless they also 2554    tab control do not necessarily change the context, unless they also
2555    change one of the above (e.g., focus). 2555    change one of the above (e.g., focus).
2556  2556

2558    component, going to a new page (including anything that would look 2558    component, going to a new page (including anything that would look
2559    to a user as if they had moved to a new page) or significantly 2559    to a user as if they had moved to a new page) or significantly
2560    re-arranging the content of a page are examples of changes of context. 2560    re-arranging the content of a page are examples of changes of context.

2569    programming techniques, but rather to what the user perceives as 2569    programming techniques, but rather to what the user perceives as

2577    these would need to have a name and be settable independently, they 2577    these would need to have a name and be settable independently, they

2586    *3.2.3 2586    *3.2.3

2589    multiple Web pages 2589    multiple Web pages
2590    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#webpagedef> within a 2590    <http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#webpagedef> within a

2597  2597 
2598  2598 
2599      Intent of this Success Criterion 2599      Intent of this Success Criterion
2600  2600 
2601The intent of this Success Criterion is to encourage the use of 2601The intent of this Success Criterion is to encourage the use of
2602consistent presentation and layout for users who interact with repeated 2602consistent presentation and layout for users who interact with repeated
2603content within a set of Web pages and need to locate specific 2603content within a set of Web pages and need to locate specific
2604information or functionality more than once. Individuals with low vision 2604information or functionality more than once. Individuals with low vision
2605who use screen magnification to display a small portion of the screen at 2605who use screen magnification to display a small portion of the screen at
2606a time often use visual cues and page boundaries to quickly locate 2606a time often use visual cues and page boundaries to quickly locate
2607repeated content. Presenting repeated content in the same order is also 2607repeated content. Presenting repeated content in the same order is also
2608important for visual users who use spatial memory or visual cues within 2608important for visual users who use spatial memory or visual cues within
2609the design to locate repeated content. 2609the design to locate repeated content.
2610  2610 
2611It is important to note that the use of the phrase "same order" in this 2611It is important to note that the use of the phrase "same order" in this
2612section is not meant to imply that subnavigation menus cannot be used or 2612section is not meant to imply that subnavigation menus cannot be used or
2613that blocks of secondary navigation or page structure cannot be used. 2613that blocks of secondary navigation or page structure cannot be used.
2614Instead, this Success Criterion is intended to assist users who interact 2614Instead, this Success Criterion is intended to assist users who interact
2615with repeated content across Web pages to be able to predict the 2615with repeated content across Web pages to be able to predict the
2616location of the content they are looking for and find it more quickly 2616location of the content they are looking for and find it more quickly
2617when they encounter it again. 2617when they encounter it again.
2618  2618 
2619Users may initiate a change in the order by using adaptive user agents 2619Users may initiate a change in the order by using adaptive user agents
2620or by setting preferences so that the information is presented in a way 2620or by setting preferences so that the information is presented in a way
2621that is most useful to them. 2621that is most useful to them.
2622  2622 
2623  2623 
2624        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 3.2.3 2624        Specific Benefits of Success Criterion 3.2.3
2625  2625 
2626  * 2626  *
2627  2627 
2628    Ensuring that repeated components occur in the same order on each 2628    Ensuring that repeated components occur in the same order on each
2629    page of a site helps users become comfortable that they will able to 2629    page of a site helps users become comfortable that they will able to
2630    predict where they can find things on each page. This helps users 2630    predict where they can find things on each page. This helps users
2631    with *cognitive limitations*, users with *low vision*, users with 2631    with *cognitive limitations*, users with *low vision*, users with
2632    *intellectual disabilities*, and also those who are *blind*. 2632    *intellectual disabilities*, and also those who are *blind*.
2633  2633 
2634  2634 
2635      Examples of Success Criterion 3.2.3 2635      Examples of Success Criterion 3.2.3
2636  2636 
2637  * 2637  *
2638  2638 
2639    *A consistently located control* 2639    *A consistently located control*
2640  2640 
2641    A search field is the last item on every Web page in a site. users 2641    A search field is the last item on every Web page in a site. users
2642    can quickly locate the search function. 2642    can quickly locate the search function.
2643  2643 
2644  * 2644  *
2645  2645 
2646    *An expanding navigation menu* 2646    *An expanding navigation menu*
2647  2647 
2648    A navigation menu includes a list of seven items with links to the 2648    A navigation menu includes a list of seven items with links to the
2649    main sections of a site. When a user selects one of these items, a 2649    main sections of a site. When a user selects one of these items, a
2650    list of subnavigation items is inserted into the top-level 2650    list of subnavigation items is inserted into the top-level
2651    navigation menu. 2651    navigation menu.
2652  2652 
2653  * 2653  *
2654  2654 
2655    *Consistently positioned skip navigation controls* 2655    *Consistently positioned skip navigation controls*
2656  2656 
2657    A "skip navigation" (or "skip to main content") link is included as 2657    A "skip navigation" (or "skip to main content") link is included as
2658    the first link on every page in a Web site. The link allows users to 2658    the first link on every page in a Web site. The link allows users to
2659    quickly bypass heading information and navigational content and 2659    quickly bypass heading information and navigational content and
2660    begin interacting with the main content of a page. 2660    begin interacting with the main content of a page.
2661  2661 
2662  * 2662  *
2663  2663 
2664    *Skip to navigation link* 2664    *Skip to navigation link*
2665  2665 
2666    Navigational content is consistently located at the end of each page 2666    Navigational content is consistently located at the end of each page
2667    in a set of Web pages. A "skip to navigation" link is consistently 2667    in a set of Web pages. A "skip to navigation" link is consistently
2668    located at the beginning of each page so that keyboard users can 2668    located at the beginning of each page so that keyboard users can
2669    easily locate it when needed. 2669    easily locate it when needed.
